conclusion: To determine the speed at t=60s, analyze the acceleration-time graph; speed is the area under the graph.
From t=0 to t=1s, acceleration increases linearly from 0 to 2 m/s².
From t=1 to t=4s, acceleration is constant at 2 m/s².
From t=4 to t=5s, acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0.
From t=5 to t=55s, acceleration is 0.
From t=55 to t=56s, acceleration decreases linearly from 0 to -2 m/s².
From t=56 to t=59s, acceleration is constant at -2 m/s².
From t=59 to t=60s, acceleration increases linearly from -2 m/s² to 0.
Calculate area for segment 1 (0 to 1s): Triangle area is 1 m/s.
Calculate area for segment 2 (1 to 4s): Rectangle area is 6 m/s.
Calculate area for segment 3 (4 to 5s): Triangle area is 1 m/s.
Calculate area for segment 4 (5 to 55s): Area is 0.
Calculate area for segment 5 (55 to 56s): Triangle area is -1 m/s.
Calculate area for segment 6 (56 to 59s): Rectangle area is -6 m/s.
Calculate area for segment 7 (59 to 60s): Triangle area is -1 m/s.
Sum areas to find total change in velocity: 0 m/s.
Final velocity at t=60s is 0 m/s since initial velocity is 0 m/s.
